Hi! Thanks for working on this =)
I see an issue with this solution, though: the use of ApiException means that the caller still doesn't get any stack trace, since ApiException overrides fillInStackTrace to do nothing. Could we use a different exception type, or make the stack trace skipping in ApiException  optional, and opt out when rethrowing?
Also, I'm wondering about API compatibility. An existing client that does something like catching `AuthorizationException` to trigger configuring security and retrying would not have to change to inspect the cause. Does the client library give any stability guarantees w.r.t. the types of exception s being thrown?
Working on this as we speak :)

@reftel Thanks for reviewing the PR. You're right about the lack of stack trace. The only other existing exception class that seems to fit here is `KafkaException`. Your other approach should work too: we could make skipping the stack trace the default behavior; and overwrite that default for this PR. I'll go with the second option for the next update.

Regarding API compatibility I'm not sure about any existing guarantee re. thrown exceptions on the client side. I'll update the PR and ask one of the committers for feedback.

As I said in the JIRA:

> Onur Karaman correctly asked about the potential performance impact of doing this check for each producer record. I did some micro-benchmarking and it could be significant (particularly if the topic name is long). I reverted the change for now until we have a chance to verify its impact via `ProducerPerformance`.
> I also submitted a PR that improves the performance of `Topic.validate()`: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3234

cc @apurvam 

@ijuma Note that this only fixes part of the problem from KAFKA-5364. I'd recommend merging it for the fix and improved test coverage, but we should leave the JIRA open.

I think in https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3223 you mentioned verifying the impact of adding topic validation in ProducerRecord through ProducerPerformance. Is that still going to happen, or are you instead going to just look at the results you provided above from TopicBenchmark?

This PR looks fine, but if somehow ProducerPerformance shows the impact is negligible, then that could influence the benefit of checking in this PR.

@apurvam I noticed one other race condition. When we abort a transaction, we clear the partitions in `newPartitionsInTransaction` and we abort unsent produce requests. The problem is that the latter happens asynchronously, so we could very well see a batch dequeued for a partition which we had already cleared. I've therefore removed the fatal transition in `ensurePartitionAdded` in the latest patch.

@onurkaraman if you produce 1 million small messages per second (say 100 bytes per message), then you only have 1000 ns per message. So, 630 ns just to validate the topic name is clearly too much. I was suggesting doing the `ProducerPerformance` with this change included to figure out if the optimised version is quick enough for us to afford the check.

The next question is whether we should bother with this optimisation if we don't use it in `ProducerRecord`. I think it is because cheap validation makes it applicable in more places, but I'd be interested in other opinions.

@gosubpl, looking into this more carefully, it seems like it is a bit more involved. If we iterate over `RecordBatch`, it will always succeed because the `count` is used to end the iteration. It seems like we'd need to update the batch iterator to verify that we reached the end of the buffer after reading the last message. The headers check would be similar.

cc @hachikuji in case he has a different opinion.

Updated
retest this please

The change lgtm. Even if it is not yet used in critical code paths I think it is still beneficial to merge it.

Regarding whether we should add it in the critical path of `ProducerRecord`: since we have disabled auto topic creation by default so only admin clients can create them which is already covered by validation, I'm less concerned if a mis-named topic would be created.

I left a comment #3234 without realizing this is already being added :) As I said I think moving forward auto topic creation will be disabled by default and even obsoleted so I'm less worried that this will be a common issue.
